headline.main: The Nueva Basque Cuisine of San Sebastian

docs.lead_paragraph: SAN Sebastian is a small, elegant seaside resort that feels frozen in time. This turn-of-the-century Basque village of 175,000 inhabitants is built around an enchanting scallop-shaped bay, protected by mountains from the ravages of the Atlantic. Expansive sandy beaches, a fishing port, wide promenades and an exuberant old town of cobbled streets lined with lively bars make it an ideal summer destination. It is just a 45-minute drive south of the French Basque towns of Bayonne and Biarritz. Before Europeans began flocking to the Costa del Sol in Spain, they came to San Sebastian -- also known by its Basque name, Donostia -- made fashionable by wealthy Spaniards in the 1880's. Most of the buildings date from the late 19th century, for this ancient site has burned to the ground more than a dozen times.

headline.main: Informal Cuisine in a Lush Hotel Atrium

docs.lead_paragraph: SEVERAL months ago the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Old Greenwich closed its upscale restaurant Conde's (except for private parties) and is now "making do" with its second-tier eating place, Winfield's Cafe, in keeping with current lighter, more informal dining habits. Conde's was part of a 1980's national trend toward small, gourmet-style restaurants that many hotel chains embraced. Economic times and changing eating patterns have been hard on such efforts. Winfield's Cafe is situated in the vast 56-foot-high glass-roof atrium that is the hotel's centerpiece. Towering columns covered by climbing greenery, ficus trees, hibiscus, philodendron and other plants, a small pond, streams and waterfall all add to the appeal. In the evening, the sound of live piano music drifts over from a small bar across the way.

headline.main: Haute Cuisine vs. the Vegetarian Menace

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Jan. 15 article on a new "Lost Generation" in the kitchen describes the inability of many members of my generation to prepare complicated meals from scratch. But you miss one of the chief causes of this calamity: rampant vegetarianism, particularly among young women.

headline.main: SAN FRANCISCO HAUTE CUISINE TAKES ROOT

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: WHILE San Francisco is known primarily for its breezy and eclectic grill-style restaurants, a handful of haute cuisine establishments are striving for national recognition. Some have already achieved it, including Campton Place, where all-American cuisine reaches a lofty level with the chef Bradley Ogden, and the seminal Chez Panisse in nearby Berkeley, whose guiding force is Alice

docs.lead_paragraph: East 58th Street between Second and Third Avenues is Little Italy uptown, a block of opulent restaurants where starched cotton tablecloths are favored over red-checked poly-blends, where tuxedoed waiters recite a list of daily specials that can go on for days, and where meatballs have been banned from menus under threat of deportation. Felidia, the most handsome and talked about of the lot, is so popular that dinner reservations are often required up to five days in advance. Virtually every evening the dining room resembles Zabar's on Saturday afternoon, and the bar, where patrons wait - sometimes an hour past their reservation time - is a bibulous holding-pen of impatience and famine. Many knowledgeable diners rave about Felidia, declaring it the best Italian restaurant in New York. All of this strikes me as most curious. Although Felidia is capable of turning out some exceptional dishes, its overall performance is uneven at best, judging from five recent visits.

headline.main: GUIDES TO THE CURRENT AMERICAN CUISINE

docs.lead_paragraph: THE American section of the cookbook shelf has been expanding in recent months, and some of the new additions are most worthwhile. Do not be put off by the title ''The California Seafood Cookbook'' (Aris Books, $11.95 paper, $17.95 hard cover). For cooks who do not live within striking distance of the Pacific, the authors, Isaac Cronin, Jay Harlow and Paul Johnson, suggest alternatives to ingredients available only on the West Coast. The recipes are excellent - a collection of contemporary preparations that feature zesty seasonings often inspired by the cuisines of Mexico, Southeast Asia and China. Classics such as sole meuni ere have not been ignored either.

headline.main: A NOUVELLE CUISINE WITH A CATALAN FLAIR

docs.lead_paragraph: JAMES M. MARKHAM is chief of the Times bureau in Madrid. By JAMES M. MARKHAM From the highway leading south from the French border, the unadorned Hotel Restaurante Ampurdan in Figueras hardly looks like one of the best places in Spain to eat. An ordinary four-story concrete structure facing the road, it is the kind of anonymous, institutional-looking establishment that practically urges the traveler farther down the highway toward the exotic beach or mountaintop that may be his destination. This is a classic instance of appearances deceiving, as your correspondent, the Michelin and Gault-Millau gastronomical guides and three generations of faithful customers can attest.

byline.original: BY KEN HOM; Ken Hom is the author of ''Ken Hom's Chinese Cookery'' (Harper & Row) and the forthcoming ''East/ West Cuisine'' (Simon & Schuster)

docs.lead_paragraph: AMERICA IS MORE A ratatouille than a melting pot. Like the ingredients in the classic French vegetable stew, the myriad ethnic and racial components of the United States have retained much of their individuality while blending into and imparting their special characteristics to the flavor of the nation. It is not straining the metaphor too much to say that American cuisine has always had the same capacity to adopt, and adapt to its singular uses, the foods, spices, herbs, ideas and techniques of many other cultures. Tex-Mex, Creole, California cuisine, to mention only a sampling of our local and regional food customs, are manifestations of this ability to accept new foods, spices and flavorings. It is a paradox of our kitchens that, until quite recently, those of us who cook did not exploit this capacity for assimilation: the products of our labors remained characteristically Anglo-Saxon or European. Today, however, that reluctance is being overcome rapidly, and American cooking is being revitalized as it manifests a remarkable openness to, and acceptance of, many new ingredients, flavors and techniques.
